okay, this has to be a FAQ, and i'm embarrassed to ask it, BUT :P

i'm new to REST but would like to give it a shot as a way of solving
some problems for multiple web servers having access to centralized
data in my university..

i'd like to configure our apache server for REST -- i.e., set up a
url-dispatcher to handle all urls on my site under a certain directory
(or pseudo-directory), so that i can dispatch the requests to a
handler..  and i can't seem to figure out how to do it without the
actual file *existing*.. i get Error 404 - Object not found! error
messages.

i've played with the SetHandler and Action apache directives, putting
them in a <Location> such as:

   <Location /test >
     Action url-dispatch /cgi-bin/handler.pl
     SetHandler url-dispatch
   </Location>

what i want is for any URL request for, say, 

   http://my.server.com/test/departments
   http://my.server.com/test/departments/engineering
   http://my.server.com/test/faculty
   http://my.server.com/test/faculty/tbsmith
   http://my.server.com/test/departments/engineering/workingpapers/jan2003

   etc., etc.

the above urls to all go to the same handler.. which then parses it
and sends it to the correct sub-script, etc.. i don't want to have to
actually have the test directory (or subdirectories) exist.

i have been through the apache docs a ba-zillion times, and looked
through newsgroups, forums, etc etc etc.. looked here and on pauls
REST pages and the REST wiki.. spent time with altavista/google, even
scoured computer shelves at barnes & noble.. but i can't seem to
figure out how to do this.. 

i don't want to have to go through the trouble of setting up re-write
rules (using mod-rewrite).. but is that what people generally do?

or is the SetHandler/Action way the easier way, but i'm just missing
something? .. what am i doing wrong?

alternatively, is there a tutorial / directions on this somewhere?

finally, what word/term/jargon does one even *use* to refer to this
phenomenon or technique? i've looked stuff up under "dispatcher", or
"URL", or "cgi" or "script", or even with specific apache terms like
"SetHandler".. but is there generally a name for this "technique" so
that i can even know how to refer to it or how to look for it?

i'm ashamed to ask such a basic question, but i would be very grateful
if anyone could point me in the right direction..

thanks.
jeff stern
